name: Monolith
description: By placing this here we want to indicate that one should take great care to not lump further new features into our existing monolith. New services may still choose to adopt a "monolith first" approach as they will presumably still be of a far smaller scope than BMP itself

name: Session-based authentication
description: This is how authentication is handled between the browser and BMP-backend today

name: Token-based authentication
description: When more than one service is used to power the client, session based authentication becomes cumbersome. We want to migrate to a fully token-based strategy where tokens are issued centrally and can be verified locally by each service

name: IAC
description: Infrastructure as code. As we move towards a multi-service architecture, we will need to become proficient in this area to avoid brittle deployments and unicorn servers

name: The twelve factor app
description: https://12factor.net/

name: CircleCI
description: Our current CI/CD provider: https://app.circleci.com/projects/project-dashboard/github/corporater/

name: GitHub
description: All our code lives here: https://github.com/corporater

name: GitHub Actions
description: Most of our automation needs are currently covered by CircleCI, but we see that GitHub Actions has good traction and might provide a good alternative for some use-cases. Killer use-case(s) and a strategy for dealing with the complexity/fragmentation that may arise from splitting efforts between GA and CircleCI needed!

name: DockerHub
description: We are currently using DockerHub as our main container repository, however, there might be benefits from switching to AWS ECR, this is currently being investigated

name: AWS ECR
description: Continuous builds are pushed here as it is easier to integrate with our IAC efforts

name: VeraCode
description: We want BMP to have a VeraCode stamp of approval for security. This certificate is important for many clients. All builds are uploaded to VeraCode and subjected to static scan, we also get manual penetration tests

name: AWS S3
description: Build artifacts (installers, tar'ed images) are published/stored here. We should consider if we can make this replace ShareFile alltogether

name: JFrog
description: Package repository. Intermediary artifacts are uploaded here and used during build process. https://corporater.jfrog.io/ui/packages

name: Camunda
description: The engine that powers our process management offering. Currently embedded in the BMP VM, but a prime candidate for deployment as a separate service

name: Prometheus
description: Exposes metrics from BMP as a standard REST endpoint. Other services should use this as well, though the usage-scope is not defined and is left up to each team

name: Grafana
description: Visualize metrics as dashboards. Used by Saas/Service&Support. They have constructed a "standard" dashboard for BMP, but Grafana itself is highly configurable

name: Figma
description: Chosen as our main tool for wireframing/prototyping and shared whiteboard

name: IntelliJ 2021
description: Still being widely used, but we would suggest upgrading to 2022

name: Visual Studio Code
description: TBD

name: IntelliJ 2022
description: Latest and greatest IntelliJ. Featuring a splash-screen that does not cause seizures

name: Maven
description: Our build tool. Used locally and by CircleCI

name: JProfiler
description: We only have a single license for this, which, coupled with a slightly convoluted workflow, means we might not be profiling as much as we should. Are there other options?

name: Cypress
description: E2E-testing platform. Can be run locally and is used by CircleCI

name: Install4j
description: Install4j solves many of the same challenges as docker/containers. Our cloud-first strategy means that we should probably put greater emphasis on how we run our services in containers and less on how they are deployed on prem

name: Snyk
description: Container images are currently scanned for library-vulnerabilites using Snyk

name: Docker
description: Our preferred container technology. All services should produce images as part of their build workflow

name: Java17
description: We are currently in the process of migrating to this. Any new services should be using this from the get-go

name: Go
description: This is being tested by the CDE-team and currently powers the backend for iac.admin

name: Terraform
description: This is our format for IAC. It is the most popular offering in this segment

name: Java8
description: Any new services/libraries/repos should not use this, though we have not taken the plunge for bmp.bmp yet

name: React
description: Our primary front-end framework. Recommended as the front-end backbone for all services

name: Spring
description: New services should be based on spring-boot. We are aware that the framework comes with a fair bit of overhead in terms of complexity and weight of JAR-files, but we feel that the gains in terms of utility, push towards good code practices and possibility of unification/streamlining between services is well worth it

name: ag-grid
description: Front-end tables. Widely used in BMP. Due to license cost and complexity may not be suitable for small use-cases in other products/services

name: Apollo-client
description: Front-end graphql client. Included here as an indication that graphql is our chosen protocol for frontend-backend communications

name: JUL
description: BMP uses JUL for logging. Other services use JUL over SLF4J
